description: From Middle English, from Old French fundement, fondement, from Latin fundāmentum (“foundation”), from fundō (“I lay the bottom, I found”). Doublet of fondamento.

entries.meaning: The bottom; the buttocks or anus.
examples: It [the Sphincter Ani] serves to purse up the Fundament, and so hinders the involuntary Evacuation of the Fæces.

entries.meaning: The underlying basis or principle for a theoretical or mathematical system.
